questions.text: A newborn presents with respiratory distress; RR=70/minute; air entry reduced in midaxilla; grunting audible with stethoscope; cyanosis on room air; mild retractions. What is his Downe’s score?
What is the most important component of surfactant?
At what stage of lung development, is surfactant seen in the type II pneumocytes?
A 29 week, 600gm baby is born in the labour room. The baby has moderate respiratory distress, with a silverman score 6. What is the next appropriate step?
Below shown is an X Ray of a preterm, 600gms who presented with abdominal distension. Which stage of Bell’s staging is this?
According to MOHFW 2016 guidelines, when should a screening for ROP be done in babies < 1200gms?
A 42 week, 1600gms newborn is born with meconium stained liquor. He is limp and apneic after the initial steps. What is the next step?
Which limb is taken as preductal as a convention in neonatal resuscitation?
What is 3 minute target for spO2% in newborns?

You are called to a crash Cesarean-section. After the birth you are concerned about the baby’s condition and assess heart rate: According to resuscitation guidelines, at which point should you commence chest compressions?
questions.correct_answer: B. Less than 60 beats per minute

questions.text: A term baby is born by emergency Caesarean section following a prolonged fetal bradycardia. The baby mad o respiratory effort and has been intubated. Baby is receiving uninterrupted breaths and chest compressions. A saturation probe placed on the baby’s right hand shows undetectable oxygen saturations and displays a heart rate only when chest compressions are ongoing. An emergency umbilical venous catheter (UVC) has been placed and heart rate remains undetectable whenever compressions are stopped. Chest compressions and breaths are currently ongoing. Baby is now 8 min old and the consultant is on their way from home. What is the next most appropriate step?

options.label: C
options.text: Suction with wide-bore catheter under direct vision

options.label: D
options.text: Turn down temperature to begin cooling the baby

questions.text: If a newborn is started on chest compressions in addition to PPV, which is of the following measure is not required?

George, a 2-weeks-old male infant, presents to the emergency Department with vomiting, diarrhea and poor feeding. Investigations show: Sodium 112 mmol/L (normal range 133-145 mmol/L) Potassium 6.8 mmol/L (normal range 3.5-6.0 mmol/L) Urea 7.8 mmol/L (normal range 2.5-8.0 mmol/L) Creatinine 30 mmol/L (normal range 20-65 mmol/L) Blood glucose 1.7 mmol/L (normal range > 2.6 mmol/L) Infection screen-negative What is the most likely cause?
A baby is born with a disorder of sexual differentiation. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia is suspected. What blood result would confirm the diagnosis?

A 2-weeks-old infant attends the Emergency Department with the following blood test results from a non-haemolysed sample: sodium 125 mmol/l, potassium 6.5 mmol/l, urea 7.9 mmol/l, creatinine 67 ?mol/l. the parents report that the baby had been vomiting after their feeds, but they put this down to simple possets. I addition, the midwife has accurately documented that the baby has lost 15% of its birth weight and not regained this. On examination of the baby’s external genitalia area you note what you think could be an enlarged penis. If the baby is a boy with 21-hydroxylase deficiency, which of the following would be most in keeping with this diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Ambiguous genitalia and a salt-losing crisis

options.label: B
options.text: An enlarged penis and a salt-losing crisis

options.label: C
options.text: An enlarged penis, salt retention and hypertension

questions.correct_answer: A. Ambiguous genitalia and a salt-losing crisis

questions.text: An infant is being investigated for persistent jaundice and has a systolic murmur consistent with pulmonary valve disease. Ophthalmological assessment reveals an anterior-segment abnormality. What is the most likely skeletal manifestation?

A Pakistani couple are referred for genetic counseling. They lost two children who both died in the first 2 years of life. They have one healthy girl, who is 3 years of age. The faulty gene has been identified and other members of their family have been tested. What is the pattern of inheritance in this disorder?
What is the inheritance of Dent disease and Lowe syndrome?
What is the inheritance in the below shown image?

You review an 8-years-old boy who attends a school for moderate learning difficulties. His neonatal history includes intrauterine growth retardation, neonatal history includes intrauterine growth retardation, neonatal hypotonia and hypoglycaemia. He was a difficult feeder and required nasogastric feeds. As an infant, he became obese. On entry to nursery school, he was referred for eating soil, paper and other objects. On examination, the boy has short stature, mild dysmorphism with almond-shaped eyes and a downturned fish-mouth appearance. He has small hands and feet, and hypogonadism. He has speech and language delay with poor development progression. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: A. Disorder of maternal uniparental disomy

questions.text: What is the inheritance of deafness, due to aminoglycosides?

You are asked to investigate a 5-years-old boy who has autistic features. His OFC is on the 89th centile, but height and weight are on the 50th centile. He also has large ears. Karyotype was normal. His mother suffered a premature menopause aged 36. What is the most likely diagnosis?
The fragile site in Fragile X syndrome is at which locus?
When does a child have a vocabulary of 50-100 words?
When does a child have a vocabulary of more than 2000 words?
When can a child make a tower of 7 cubes and put three words together ie subject, verb, object?
When can a child throw ball overhand, uses scissors to cut a picture and tell a story?
When can a child name 4 colors and name heavier of 2 weights?
Which short stature is depicted by the third curve from below?
Which short stature is depicted by second curve from below?
In which short stature, bone age approximately the chronological age?
A 2 yr old child has acute diarrhea since 4 days. He is thirsty, turgor goes back slowly and is playful. What should be the next plan as per WHO?
What is the total osmolarity in the Low osmolarity ORS?
What is the amount of trisodium citrate in gms in low osmolarity ORS?
What is the dose of zinc in a 3 months old child with diarrhea?
Which statement is not true about this 6 months old child with skin lesions?

options.label: B
options.text: Dose of zinc is 3mg/kg for 2 yrs

questions.correct_answer: B. Dose of zinc is 3mg/kg for 2 yrs

questions.text: What is the recommended maintainence fluid in children?
What is the composition of potassium in Ringer lactate in meq/L?
Which of the following has highest arterial pO2 during fetal life?
At what arterial pO2 in mmHg, ductus arteriosus closes?
You are evaluating a newborn in the nursery for hypotonia, dysmorphic features, and a heart murmur. Based on these features, what is the most likely chromosome abnormality and heart defect?
questions.correct_answer: B. Trisomy 21: complete atrioventricular canal defect

questions.text: Below is shown an echocardiogram of a cyanotic newborn. What would you suspect in the baby?

You are caring for a 2.2-kg term infant with cleft palate and a small chin. A fetal echocardiogram diagnosed truncus arteriosus, which was confirmed postnatally. There is a small or absent thymus on the echocardiogram. What is most likely underlying genetic abnormality?

Your gastroenterology colleagues request your help to evaluate a murmur in a 3-year-old with a history of jaundice and cholestasis. You note that he has a history of mild developmental delay and has unusual facial features (broad forehead, deep-set eyes, pointed chin). The chest X-ray shows a normal cardiac silhouette, but butterfly-shaped vertebrae. You hear normal S1 and S2, no valve clicks, and peripheral PS murmurs bilaterally. What gene defect should you test for?

options.label: B
options.text: PTPN11 mutation in the RAS/MAP pathway

questions.text: A previously normal newborn infant in a community hospital nursery is noted to be cyanotic at 14 hours of life. She is placed on a face mask with oxygen flowing at 10 L/min. She remains cyanotic, and her pulse oximetry reading does not change. An arterial blood gas shows her Pa02 to be 23 mm Hg. Bilateral breath sounds are present, and she has no murmur. She is breathing deeply and quickly, but she is not retracting. While you are waiting for the transport team from the nearby children's hospital, you should initiate which of the following?
A 6 weeks old baby presents with failure to thrive and feeding diaphoresis. His X Ray is shown below. This anamoly subtype represents what % of TAPVC cases?

You are evaluating a 3-month-old boy in your office who you know to have tetralogy of Fallot. His mother informs you that the infant has had fever, diarrhea, and poor feeding in the last 24 hours. On physical examination, you note cyanosis of the extremities and perioral area, tachypnea, hyperpnea, and a heart rate of 180 beats per min. At the last visit you recall a harsh 3/6 systolic ejection murmur; today you do not hear a murmur. Of the following, the MOST appropriate management strategy is to:

options.label: B
options.text: Reassure his mother because the murmur is gone

options.label: C
options.text: Order echocardiogram to evaluate the pulmonary valve

options.label: D
options.text: Place him in the knee–chest position with oxygen

questions.correct_answer: D. Place him in the knee–chest position with oxygen

questions.text: Which of the following agent shall not be used in the previous child?
What does the figure below shows which shunt?
The below shown shape on a Chest X Ray is due to which chamber hypertrophy?
The below shown rash is seen in which phase of Kawasaki disease?

A 6-year-old boy presents to the emergency room with complaints of ankle pain and rash. He is noted on exam to have bilateral ankle swelling, which is periarticular and nonpitting in nature. He has a purpuric rash on his bilateral lower extremities, scrotum; and buttocks; it is nonblanching and nonmigratory. His platelet count and hemoglobin are normal and his WBC count is elevated to 15,000/mm3. PT and aPTT are normal. Urinalysis is negative. What anticipatory guidance do you provide the family?

options.label: A
options.text: His ankle swelling should be treated with NSAIDs and will become chronic

options.label: B
options.text: The risk of nephritis will be present for the next several years and he should be screened regular during that time

options.label: C
options.text: The onset of abdominal pain is most likely from his NSAID and should be treated symptomatically.

options.label: D
options.text: The rash may come and go for weeks to months following the initial presentation

questions.correct_answer: D. The rash may come and go for weeks to months following the initial presentation

questions.text: The above child is at risk of nephritis within how many weeks of onset of disease?
If the above child shows microscopic hematuria and proteinuria, the kidney biopsy shall show proliferation of
According to American Heart Association, 2015 Jones criteria, low risk population would mean all age prevalence of RHD of………… per 1000 population per year
According to American Heart Association, 2015 Jones criteria, new Major criteria included for moderate to high risk populations is
According to American Heart Association, 2015 Jones criteria, new Major criteria included for moderate to high risk populations is
What is the most common cause of pneumonia in newborns all over the world?
What is the most common bacterial cause of pneumonia in children from 3 weeks of life to 3 yrs of life in India and the World?

A 4-year-old previously healthy boy presents with fever to 102.5Åã F, sore throat, irritability, and refusal to eat or drink. Symptoms began that morning and have progressed over the past few hours. You note the child to be ill appearing, leaning forward, and drooling. There are no ill contacts and the child has received all immunizations. You keep the child comfortable with his mother and immediately contact anesthesia and otolaryngology to assist with further management. If neck films were ordered, the most likely finding would be:

options.label: D
options.text: Irregularity of the tracheal air column

questions.text: A 2 yrs old boy presents to you with fever, barky cough and cold. Since last 2 days, he has developed inspiratory sound at rest, and he is not able to drink water. He appears blue. Which of the following should be next step?
Recurrent Pneumonia is defined as

options.label: A
options.text: 2 or more episodes in 1 yr or 3 episodes ever

options.label: B
options.text: 3 or more episodes in 1 yr or 4 episodes ever

questions.correct_answer: A. 2 or more episodes in 1 yr or 3 episodes ever

questions.text: A 7 yr old child with a 3-yr history of cough, intermittent wheezing, and poor growth has 2 sweat chloride values of 36 and 41 mEq/L. Additional diagnostic testing to rule out cystic fibrosis should include:

options.label: D
options.text: DNA analysis for the DeltaF508 mutation

questions.text: DeltaF508 mutation has a functional defect on the CFTR channel. It leads to

options.label: B
options.text: Defect in protein trafficking with ubiquitination and degradation in endoplasmic reticulum/Golgi body

options.label: C
options.text: Defective regulation; CFTR not activated by adenosine triphosphate or cyclic adenosine monophosphate

options.label: D
options.text: Reduced chloride transport through CFTR at the apical membrane

questions.correct_answer: B. Defect in protein trafficking with ubiquitination and degradation in endoplasmic reticulum/Golgi body

questions.text: The most common cause of pneumonia in children with cystic fibrosis is
What is the risk of recurrence if a child has no risk factors in case of febrile seizures?

Anne, a 6-years-old girl, is seen by her general practitioner. Her mother and school teacher have noticed she has episodes where she stops her activity for a few seconds, stares blankly ahead and then resumes the activity as if she had never stopped. These episodes happen many times a day. She has no other medical problems and there is no family history of note. The EEG during an episode is shown Choose the most likely diagnosis.

Vijay is a 5-months-old infant who has been seen repeatedly by his general practitioner because of colic. His mother brings him to the Accident and Emergency department as he is having episodes of suddenly throwing his head and arms forward. These episodes occur in repetitive bursts. His mother thinks they may be something more than just colic, as he is now not smiling or supporting his head as well as he did previously. He was born at term by normal vaginal delivery and has no other medical problems. His back has a skin lesion as shown Choose the most likely diagnosis.

options.label: B
options.text: Childhood Rolandic epilepsy (benign epilepsy with centro-temporal spikes)

questions.text: Drug of choice for the infant in previous question is
A 15 yr old girl presents with frequent jerks more in the awakening. Her sister also died of similar complaints. Her EEG on photic stimulation is shown below. Which drug should not be used in her?
A 2 yrs old child is brought with fever and coma since 5 days. His T2W MRI brain image is shown. What should be the next step?

Finlay, a 5-years-old boy, recently had a birthday party at his local farm. Since then he has had 3 days of diarrhoea. The loose stool had some blood in it. His mother is concerned as he is still not himself. He appears to be very pale and has not passed urine for 12 hours. He has no other medical problems and is not normally on any medication. On examination you note that he has pale conjunctivae. His blood pressure is 120/70 mmHg. You decide to take some blood tests and get the following results: • Haemoglobin: 76 g/L; white blood cells: 14.2 x 109/L; platelet count: 50 x 109/L • Creatinine: 200 ?mol/L (normal: 20-80 ?mol/L) • Prothrombin time: 13 seconds (control:12-15 s) • Activated partial thromboplastin time: 34 seconds (control: 25-35 s) What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is not correctly matched?

A 15 yrs old boy with a 12-yr history of microscopic hematuria is noted to have bilateral high frequency sensorineural hearing loss, blood pressure of 140/90 mm Hg, serum creatinine of 1.5 mg/dl, and urinary protein of 2,000 mg/24 hr. This patient’s mother also has microscopic hematuria. What % of this disease is autosomal dominant?
What is the drug of choice for a child with steroid dependent nephrotic syndrome, who developed hypertension, posterior subcapsular cataract, impaired glucose tolerance and short stature?
